cleaned_text: Meditation Meditation is a practice in which an individual uses a technique - such as [mindfulness](/wiki/Mindfulness), or focusing the [mind](/wiki/Mind) on a particular object, thought, or activity - to train [attention](/wiki/Attention) and [awareness](/wiki/Awareness), and achieve a mentally clear and emotionally calm and state. [[1]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWalshShapiro2006228-229-1) [[2]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECahnPolich2006180-2) [[3]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJevningWallaceBeidebach1992415-3) [[4]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoleman1988107-4) [[web 1]](#cite_note-MW-5) [[web 2]](#cite_note-Oxford-6) Meditation is practiced in numerous religious traditions. The earliest records of meditation ( [dhyana](/wiki/Dhyana_in_Hinduism)) are found in the [Upanishads](/wiki/Upanishads), and meditation plays a salient role in the contemplative repertoire of [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism), [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism) and [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism). [[5]](#cite_note-:5-7) Since the 19th century, Asian meditative techniques have spread to other cultures where they have also found application in non-spiritual contexts, such as business and health. [[6]](#cite_note-Sun_2019_pp._45-55-8) Meditation may significantly reduce [stress](/wiki/Stress_(biology)), [anxiety](/wiki/Anxiety), [[11]](#cite_note-auto-13) of meditation](/wiki/Effects_of_meditation) on health ( [psychological](/wiki/Psychology), [neurological](/wiki/Neurology), and [cardiovascular](/wiki/Cardiovascular)) and other areas. Etymology[ English meditation is derived from [Old French](/wiki/Old_French) in turn from [Latin](/wiki/Latin) [meditatio](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/meditatio) ponder". [[12]](#cite_note-14) [[13]](#cite_note-oel-15) In the [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic) tradition, the use of the term meditatio as part of a formal, stepwise process of meditation goes back to at least the 12th century monk [Guigo II](/wiki/Guigo_II), [[13]](#cite_note-oel-15) [[14]](#cite_note-16) before which the Greek word [Theoria](/wiki/Theoria) was used for the same purpose. Apart from its historical usage, the term meditation was introduced as a translation for Eastern [spiritual practices](/wiki/Spiritual_practice), referred to as dhyna in [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism) and [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism) and which comes from the meaning contemplate or meditate. [[15]](#cite_note-17) [[16]](#cite_note-feurstein06-18) [[17]](#cite_note-19) The term "meditation" in English may also refer to practices from Islamic [Sufism](/wiki/Sufism), [[18]](#cite_note-20) or other traditions such as Jewish [Kabbalah](/wiki/Kabbalah) and [Hesychasm](/wiki/Hesychasm). [[19]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoleman1988-21) Definitions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=2)] [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=3)] No universally accepted definition[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=4)] Meditation has proven difficult to define as it covers a wide range of dissimilar practices in different traditions. In popular usage, the word "meditation" and the phrase "meditative practice" are often used imprecisely to designate practices found across many [cultures](/wiki/Culture). [[19]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoleman1988-21) [[20]](#cite_note-carroll05-22) These can include almost anything that is claimed to train the attention of mind or to teach calm or compassion. [[21]](#cite_note-:2-23) There remains no definition of necessary and sufficient criteria for meditation that has achieved universal or widespread acceptance within the modern scientific [community](/wiki/Community). In 1971, [Claudio Naranjo](/wiki/Claudio_Naranjo) noted that "The word 'meditation' has been used to designate a variety of practices that differ enough from one another so that we may find trouble defining what meditation is." [[22]](#cite_note-naranjo72-24): 6 A 2009 study noted a "persistent lack of consensus in the [literature](/wiki/Literature)" and a "seeming intractability of defining meditation". [[23]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBondOspinaHootonBialy2009135-25) Separation of technique from tradition[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=5)] Some of the difficulty in precisely defining meditation has been in recognizing the particularities of the many various [traditions](/wiki/Tradition); [[24]](#cite_note-intro_to_consciousness-26) and theories and practice can differ within a [tradition](/wiki/Tradition). [[25]](#cite_note-Dunne_@_Stanford-27) Taylor noted that even within a [faith](/wiki/Faith) such as "Hindu" or "Buddhist", schools and individual teachers may teach distinct types of meditation. [[26]](#cite_note-taylor99-28): 2 Ornstein noted that "Most techniques of meditation do not exist as solitary practices but are only artificially separable from an entire system of practice and belief." [[27]](#cite_note-ornstein72-29): 143 For instance, while monks meditate as part of their everyday lives, they also engage in the codified rules and live together in monasteries in specific cultural settings that go along with their meditative practices. Dictionary definitions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=6)] Dictionaries give both the meaning of "think[ing] deeply about (something)"; [[web 2]](#cite_note-Oxford-6) as well as the popular usage of "focusing one's mind for a period of time", [[web 2]](#cite_note-Oxford-6) "the act of giving your attention to only one thing, either as a religious activity or as a way of becoming calm and relaxed", [[web 3]](#cite_note-30) and "to engage in mental exercise (such as concentrating on one's breathing or repetition of a [mantra](/wiki/Mantra)) for the purpose of reaching a heightened level of spiritual awareness." [[web 1]](#cite_note-MW-5) Scholarly definitions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=7)] In modern [psychological](/wiki/Psychology) research, meditation has been defined and characterized in various ways. Many of these emphasize the role of [attention](/wiki/Attention) [[19]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoleman1988-21) [[28]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWalshShapiro2006-31) [[29]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECahnPolich2006-32) [[30]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJevningWallaceBeidebach1992-33) and characterize the practice of meditation as attempts to get beyond the reflexive, "discursive to achieve a deeper, more devout, or more relaxed state. Bond et al. (2009) identified criteria for defining a practice as meditation "for use in a comprehensive systematic review of the therapeutic use of meditation", using "a 5-round [Delphi study](/wiki/Delphi_method) with a panel of 7 experts in meditation research" who were also trained in diverse but empirically highly studied (Eastern-derived or clinical) forms of meditation [[note 4]](#cite_note-38): three main criteria ... as essential to any meditation practice: the use of a defined technique, logic relaxation, [[note 5]]and a self-induced state/mode. Other criteria deemed important [but not essential] involve a state of psychophysical relaxation, the use of a self-focus skill or anchor, the presence of a state of suspension of logical thought processes, a religious/spiritual/philosophical context, or a state of mental silence. [[23]] ... It is plausible that meditation is best thought of as a natural category of techniques best captured by ' [family resemblances]' ... or by the related ['prototype' model of concepts]." [[32]] Several other definitions of meditation have been used by influential modern reviews of research on meditation across multiple [traditions](/wiki/Tradition): [[note 6]](#cite_note-43) - Walsh & Shapiro (2006): "Meditation refers to a family of self-regulation practices that focus on training attention and awareness in order to bring mental processes under greater voluntary control and thereby foster general mental well-being and development and/or specific capacities such as calm, clarity, and concentration" [[1]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWalshShapiro2006228-229-1) - Cahn & Polich (2006): "Meditation is used to describe practices that self-regulate the body and mind, thereby affecting mental events by engaging a specific attentional set.... regulation of attention is the central commonality across the many divergent methods" [[2]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECahnPolich2006180-2) - Jevning et al. (1992): "We define meditation... as a stylized mental technique... repetitively practiced for the purpose of attaining a subjective experience that is frequently described as very restful, silent, and of heightened alertness, often characterized as blissful" [[3]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJevningWallaceBeidebach1992415-3) - Goleman (1988): "the need for the meditator to retrain his attention, whether through concentration or mindfulness, is the single invariant ingredient in... every meditation system" [[4]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoleman1988107-4) Classifications[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=8)] Focused and open methods[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=9)] In the West, meditation techniques have often been classified in two broad categories, which in actual practice are often combined: focused (or concentrative) meditation and open monitoring (or [mindfulness](/wiki/Mindfulness)) meditation: [[35]](#cite_note-lutz08-44) Direction of mental attention... A practitioner can focus intensively on one particular object (so-called concentrative meditation), on all mental events that enter the field of awareness (so-called mindfulness meditation), or both specific focal points and the field of awareness. [[36]] Focused methods include [paying attention to the breath](/wiki/Anapanasati), to an idea or feeling (such as [mett](/wiki/Mett%C4%81) - loving-kindness), to a [kan](/wiki/K%C5%8Dan), or to a [mantra](/wiki/Mantra) (such as in [transcendental meditation](/wiki/Transcendental_Meditation)), and single point meditation. [[37]](#cite_note-46) [[38]](#cite_note-47) Open monitoring methods include [mindfulness](/wiki/Mindfulness), [shikantaza](/wiki/Shikantaza) and states. [[39]](#cite_note-48) Other possible Another [typology](/wiki/Typology_(disambiguation)) divides and reflective practices: [[40]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGangadharanHemamalini202170-49) [[41]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAguirre201818-20-50) - concentrative: focused attention, including breath meditation, TM, and visualizations; - generative: developing qualities like loving kindness and compassion; - receptive: open monitoring; - reflective: systematic investigation, [contemplation](/wiki/Contemplation). The Buddhist tradition often divides meditative practice into [samatha](/wiki/Samatha-vipassana), or calm abiding, [[42]](#cite_note-51) [[43]](#cite_note-52) and [vipassana](/wiki/Vipassana), insight. [Mindfulness of breathing](/wiki/Anapanasati), a form of focused attention, calms down the mind; this calmed mind can then investigate the nature of reality, [[44]](#cite_note-berkeley.edu-53) [[45]](#cite_note-54) [[46]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPerez-De-AlbenizHolmes2000-55) by monitoring the fleeting and ever-changing constituents of experience, by reflective investigation, or by "turning back the radiance," focusing awareness on awareness itself and discerning the true nature of [mind](/wiki/Mind) as [awareness](/wiki/Awareness) itself. Matko and Sedlmeier (2019) "call into the common division into "focused attention" and "open-monitoring" practices." They argue for "two orthogonal dimensions along which meditation techniques could be classified," namely "activation" and "amount of body orientation," proposing seven clusters of techniques: "mindful observation, body-centered meditation, visual concentration, contemplation, affect-centered meditation, mantra meditation, and meditation with movement." [[47]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatkoSedlmeier2019-56) Jonathan Shear argues that [transcendental meditation](/wiki/Transcendental_Meditation_technique) is an "automatic self-transcending" technique, different from focused attention and open monitoring. [[48]](#cite_note-Travis,_F._2010-57) In this kind of practice, "there is no attempt to sustain any particular condition at all. Practices of this kind, once started, are reported to automatically "transcend" their own activity and disappear, to be started up again later if appropriate." [[48]](#cite_note-Travis,_F._2010-57) [[note 7]](#cite_note-58) Yet, Shear also states that "automatic self-transcending" also applies to the way other techniques such as from Zen and Qigong are practiced by experienced meditators "once they had become effortless and automatic [[48]](#cite_note-Travis,_F._2010-57) Technique[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=11)] Posture[ [half-lotus](/wiki/Ardha_Padmasana)), cross-legged [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism) and [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism), [[49]](#cite_note-59) although other postures such as sitting, supine (lying), and standing are also used. Meditation is also sometimes done while walking, known as [kinhin](/wiki/Kinhin), while doing a simple task mindfully, known as [samu](/wiki/Samu_(Zen)), or while lying down, known as [shavasana](/wiki/Shavasana). [[50]](#cite_note-60) [[51]](#cite_note-61) Postures involve focus attention and move body coordinately or hold still with rhythmic inhalation and exhalation. [[52]](#cite_note-62) Frequency[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=13)] The [Transcendental Meditation](/wiki/Transcendental_Meditation) technique recommends practice of 20 minutes twice per day. [[53]](#cite_note-huffingtonpost.co.uk-63) Some techniques suggest less time, [[44]](#cite_note-berkeley.edu-53) especially when starting meditation, [[54]](#cite_note-64) and [Richard Davidson](/wiki/Richard_Davidson) has quoted research saying benefits can be achieved with a practice of only 8 minutes per day. [[55]](#cite_note-abcnews1-65) Research shows improvement in meditation time with simple oral and video training. [[56]](#cite_note-66) Some meditators practice for much longer, [[57]](#cite_note-67) [[58]](#cite_note-68) particularly when on a course or [retreat](/wiki/Spiritual_retreat). [[59]](#cite_note-69) Some meditators find practice best in [the hours [[60]](#cite_note-70) Supporting aids[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=14)] Use of prayer beads[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=15)] Some religions have traditions of using [prayer beads](/wiki/Prayer_beads) as tools in devotional beads and [Christian rosaries](/wiki/Rosary_based_prayers) consist of pearls or beads linked together by a thread. [[61]](#cite_note-Binz3-71) [[62]](#cite_note-Sach-72) The Roman Catholic rosary is a string of beads containing five sets with ten small beads. The Hindu [japa mala](/wiki/Japa_mala) has 108 beads (the figure 108 in itself having spiritual significance), as well as those used in [Gaudiya Vaishnavism](/wiki/Gaudiya_Vaishnavism), the [[64]](#cite_note-74) [[65]](#cite_note-Vishnu-75) Each bead is counted once as a person recites a [mantra](/wiki/Mantra) until the person has gone all the way around the mala. [[65]](#cite_note-Vishnu-75) The Muslim [misbaha](/wiki/Misbaha) has 99 beads. There is also quite a variance when it comes to materials used for beads. Beads made from seeds of [rudraksha](/wiki/Rudraksha) trees are considered sacred by devotees of [Shiva](/wiki/Shiva), while followers of [Vishnu](/wiki/Vishnu) revere the wood that comes from the tulsi plant. [[66]](#cite_note-76) Striking the meditator[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=16)] The Buddhist literature has many stories of [Enlightenment](/wiki/Enlightenment_in_Buddhism) being attained through disciples being struck by their masters. According to T. Griffith Foulk, the [encouragement stick](/wiki/Keisaku) was an integral part of the [Zen](/wiki/Zen) practice: In the Rinzai monastery where I trained in the mid-1970s, according to an unspoken etiquette, monks who were sitting earnestly and well were shown respect by being hit vigorously and often; those known as laggards were ignored by the hall monitor or given little taps if they requested to be hit. Nobody asked about the 'meaning' of the stick, nobody explained, and nobody ever complained about its use. [[67]] Using a narrative[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=17)] Neuroscientist and long-time meditator Richard Davidson has expressed the view that having a narrative can help the maintenance of daily practice. [[55]](#cite_note-abcnews1-65) For instance he himself [prostrates](/wiki/Prostration_(Buddhism)) to the teachings, and meditates "not primarily for my benefit, but for the benefit of others". [[55]](#cite_note-abcnews1-65) Meditation traditions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=18)] Origins[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=19)] The history of meditation is intimately bound up with the religious context within which it was practiced. [[68]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEverlyLating2002199-202-78) Rossano has suggested that the emergence of the capacity for focused attention, an element of many methods of meditation, may have contributed to the latest phases of human biological evolution. [[69]](#cite_note-79) Some of the earliest references to meditation, as well as proto- [Samkhya](/wiki/Samkhya), are found in the [Upanishads](/wiki/Upanishads) of India. [[70]](#cite_note-80) [[71]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELusthaus2018-81) The earliest clear references to meditation are in the middle [Upanishads](/wiki/Upanishads) and the [Mahabharata](/wiki/Mahabharata) (including the [Bhagavad the earlier Upanishad](/wiki/Brihadaranyaka_Upanishad) is describing meditation when it states that "having become calm and concentrated, one perceives the self (tman) system were referred to as [salvation](/wiki/Salvation)-path. It has three parts called the [Ratnatraya](/wiki/Ratnatraya) "Three Jewels": right perception and faith, right knowledge and right conduct. [[75]](#cite_note-Ratna_traya-85) Meditation in [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism) aims at realizing the self, attaining [salvation](/wiki/Salvation), and taking the soul to complete freedom. [[76]](#cite_note-blessings-86) It aims to reach and to remain in the pure state of soul which is believed to be pure consciousness, beyond any attachment or aversion. The practitioner strives to be just a knower-seer (gyata-drashta). Jain meditation can be broadly and Shukla Dhyana.[ [clarification on a [mantra](/wiki/Mantra). [[77]](#cite_note-HN4U-87) A mantra could be either a combination of core letters or words on deity or themes. There is a rich tradition of [mantra](/wiki/Mantra) in [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism). All Jain followers irrespective of their sect, whether [Digambara](/wiki/Digambar) or [vetmbara](/wiki/Svetambara), practice [mantra](/wiki/Mantra). [Mantra](/wiki/Mantra) chanting is an important part of daily lives of Jain monks and followers. [Mantra](/wiki/Mantra) chanting can be done either loudly or silently in mind. [[77]](#cite_note-HN4U-87) [Contemplation](/wiki/Contemplation) is a very old and important meditation technique. The practitioner meditates deeply on subtle facts. In agnya vichya, one contemplates on seven facts - life and non-life, the inflow, bondage, stoppage and removal of [karmas](/wiki/Karma), and the final accomplishment of liberation. In apaya vichya, one contemplates on the incorrect insights one indulges, which eventually develops right insight. In vipaka vichya, one reflects on the eight causes or basic types of [karma](/wiki/Karma). In sansathan vichya, one thinks about the vastness of the universe and the loneliness of the soul. [[77]](#cite_note-HN4U-87) Buddhism[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=22)] [Buddhists](/wiki/Buddhism) pursue meditation as part of the path toward [awakening](/wiki/Bodhi) and [nirvana](/wiki/Nirvana). [[note 8]](#cite_note-89) The closest words for meditation in the classical languages of [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism) are [bhvan](/wiki/Bhavana) ("development"), and the core practices [samdhi](/wiki/Sam%C4%81dhi). [[note 10]](#cite_note-91) While most classical and meditation guides are school-specific, [[note 11]](#cite_note-92) the root meditative practices of various body recollections and [breath meditation](/wiki/Anapanasati) have been preserved and transmitted in almost all [Buddhist traditions](/wiki/Schools_of_Buddhism), through [Buddhist texts](/wiki/Buddhist_texts) like the [Dhyana sutras](/wiki/Dhyana_sutras), and through oral teacher-student transmissions. These ancient practices are supplemented with various distinct interpretations of, and developments in, these practices. The [Theravda](/wiki/Therav%C4%81da) tradition stresses the development of [samatha](/wiki/Samatha-vipassana) and vipassana, postulating over fifty methods for developing mindfulness based on the Satipatthana Sutta, [[note 12]](#cite_note-93) and forty for developing concentration based the [Visuddhimagga](/wiki/Visuddhimagga). The [Tibetan tradition](/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism) incorporated [Sarvastivada](/wiki/Sarvastivada) and Tantric practices, wedded with [Madhyamaka](/wiki/Madhyamaka) philosophy, and developed thousands of visualization meditations. [[note 13]](#cite_note-94) Via the Dhyana sutras, which are based on the Sarvastivada-tradition, the Zen-tradition incorporated mindfulness and breath-meditation. Downplaying of and [[80]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcRae1986116-96) the [awareness](/wiki/Awareness) of immanent death), the early Chan-tradition developed the notions or practices of wu nian ("no thought, no "fixation on thought, such as one's own views, experiences, and the one without wavering," [[85]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcRae1986143-101) turning the attention from the objects of experience, to the [nature of mind](/wiki/Nature_of_mind), the perceiving subject itself, which is equated with [Buddha-nature](/wiki/Buddha-nature). [[86]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharf2014939-102) The [Silk Road transmission of Buddhism](/wiki/Silk_Road_transmission_of_Buddhism) introduced meditation to other Asian countries, reaching China in the 2nd century CE, [[87]](#cite_note-103) and Japan in the 6th century CE. [[88]](#cite_note-104) In the modern era, Buddhist meditation techniques have become popular in the wider world, due to the influence of [Buddhist modernism](/wiki/Buddhist_modernism) on Asian [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism), and [western lay with many non-Buddhists taking-up meditative practices. The modernized concept of mindfulness (based on the Buddhist term [sati](/wiki/Sati_(Buddhism))) and related meditative practices have in turn led to [mindfulness based therapies](/wiki/Mindfulness#Therapy_programs). [[89]](#cite_note-105) Dhyana[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=23)] [Dhyana](/wiki/Dhy%C4%81na_in_Buddhism) may have been an original contribution of [Gautama Buddha](/wiki/Gautama_Buddha) (5th cent. BCE), the founder of [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism). [[90]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993-106) While often presented as a form of focused attention or concentration, as in Buddhagosa's Theravada classic the [Visuddhimagga](/wiki/Visuddhimagga) ("Path of purification, 5th c. CE), according to a number contemporary scholars and scholar-practitioners, it is actually a description of the development of perfected equanimity and mindfulness, apparently induced by satipatthana, an open monitoring of the breath, without trying to regulate it. The same description, in a different formula, can be found in the [bojjhanga](/wiki/Bojjhanga), the "seven factors of awakening," and may therefore refer to the core program of early Buddhist bhavana. [[91]](#cite_note-107) According to Vetter, dhyana seems to be a natural development from the sense-restraint and moral constrictions prescribed by the Buddhist tradition. [[92]](#cite_note-108) [[93]](#cite_note-109) Samatha and vipassana[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=24)] The Buddha identified two paramount mental qualities that arise from wholesome meditative practice or bhavana, namely [samatha](/wiki/Samatha) ("calm," "serenity" "tranquility") and [vipassana](/wiki/Vipassana) (insight). As the developing tradition started to emphasize the value of liberating insight, and dhyana came to be understood as concentration, [[94]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993131-110) [[95]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi-xxxvii-111) [samatha](/wiki/Samatha-vipassana) and [vipassana](/wiki/Vipassana) were understood as two distinct meditative techniques. In this understanding, [samatha](/wiki/Samatha-vipassana) steadies, composes, unifies and concentrates the mind, while [vipassana](/wiki/Samatha-vipassana) enables one to see, explore and discern "formations" (conditioned phenomena based on the five [aggregates](/wiki/Skandha)). [[note 14]](#cite_note-112) According to this understanding, which is central to Theravada orthodoxy but also plays a role in [Tibetan Buddhism](/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism), through the meditative development of serenity, one is able to weaken the obscuring [hindrances](/wiki/Five_Hindrances) and bring the mind to a collected, pliant, and still state ( [samadhi](/wiki/Samadhi)). This quality of mind then supports the development of insight and wisdom ( [Prajñ](/wiki/Praj%C3%B1%C4%81_(Buddhism))) which is the quality of mind that can "clearly see" (vi-passana) the nature of phenomena. What exactly is to be seen varies within the Buddhist traditions. In Theravada, all phenomena are to be seen as [impermanent](/wiki/Anicca), [suffering](/wiki/Dukkha), [not-self](/wiki/Anatta) and [empty](/wiki/Shunyata). When this happens, one develops [dispassion](/wiki/Nonattachment_(philosophy)) (viraga) for all phenomena, including all negative qualities and hindrances and lets them go. It is through the release of the hindrances and ending of craving through the meditative development of insight that one gains liberation. [[96]](#cite_note-113) Hinduism[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Meditation&action=edit§ion=25)] There are many schools and styles of meditation within [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism). [[74]](#cite_note-Flood-84) In pre-modern and traditional [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism), Yoga to recognize 'pure awareness', or 'pure consciousness', undisturbed by the workings of the mind, as one's eternal self. In [Advaita Vedanta](/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta) [jivatman](/wiki/Jivatman), individual self, is recognized as illusory, and in Reality identical with the omnipresent and [non-dual](/wiki/Nonduality_(spirituality)) [tman](/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism))- [Brahman](/wiki/Brahman). In the [dualistic Yoga school](/wiki/Yoga_(philosophy)) and [Samkhya](/wiki/Samkhya), the Self is called [Purusha](/wiki/Purusha), a pure consciousness undisturbed by [Prakriti](/wiki/Prakriti), 'nature'. Depending on the tradition, the liberative event is named [moksha](/wiki/Moksha), vimukti or [kaivalya](/wiki/Kaivalya).
